importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the third week of the ongoing government shutdown, highlighting the prolonged impact on federal workers and public services.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown has lasted for over a week and is now in its third week, exacerbating financial strain on federal employees who have been furloughed or unpaid.

keyTakeAways: Federal workers, including contractors and employees from departments like the Department of Commerce and Social Security Administration, are facing financial hardship due to a government shutdown.
A food bank event in Landover, Maryland, served over 370 households — more than double the expected number — showing the scale of need among furloughed federal employees.
Federal contractors and employees such as Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams have no pay for the month, leading them to rely on food banks for survival.
Lawmakers have failed to reach agreement on compensation, with GOP Sen. Ron Johnson proposing payment only for workers still working, while Democrats advocate for full pay for all federal workers.
The Capital Area Food Bank, in partnership with No Limits Outreach Ministries, organized the food distribution event, which required federal employees to show work IDs for access.

Pamelia Carter, a 38-year federal employee in the Department of Agriculture and executive director of No Limits Outreach Ministries, noted the unprecedented scale of federal workers attending the event, calling it a stark contrast to regular food outreach programs.

namedEntities.name: Summer Kerksick
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal contractor and market research analyst with the Rural Export Center, US Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a representative example of a federal worker impacted by the shutdown, personally expressing financial distress and reliance on food assistance.

namedEntities.name: Ron Johnson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Introduced a bill to pay only federal workers who are actively working during the shutdown, reflecting a partisan divide on the fairness and scope of compensation.

namedEntities.name: Pamelia Carter
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Executive director of No Limits Outreach Ministries and former federal employee in the Department of Agriculture
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provides firsthand insight into the scale of the crisis, having experienced multiple shutdowns and witnessing a dramatic increase in federal worker need during this event.

namedEntities.name: Capital Area Food Bank
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Food bank in the Washington, D.C. area
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Organized a food distribution event for federal workers, which served over 370 households — a significant increase from expected attendance — indicating widespread hardship.

namedEntities.name: No Limits Outreach Ministries
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Local religious organization partnering with the Capital Area Food Bank
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Co-organized the food bank event for federal workers, demonstrating community efforts to respond to public need during a government shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Rural Export Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Division within the US Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Employer of Summer Kerksick, illustrating how federal contractors and non-essential staff are affected by the shutdown and furloughs.

namedEntities.name: Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Housing a federal contractor who is impacted by the shutdown, showing how departments beyond the core executive branch are affected.

namedEntities.name: Department of Agriculture
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Employer of Pamelia Carter, showing that workers across multiple departments face furloughs and financial instability.

namedEntities.name: Social Security Administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Employer of Rolanda Williams, illustrating that even core federal agencies are now facing economic hardship due to the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Landover, Maryland
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Location of the food bank event
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The site of the event where federal workers gathered, emphasizing geographic and community-level impact of the shutdown.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As the government shutdown enters its third week, over 1.4 million federal employees—including contractors and staff from the Department of Commerce, Department of Agriculture, and Social Security Administration—have been furloughed or are working without pay. In response, a food bank event in Landover, Maryland, organized by the Capital Area Food Bank and No Limits Outreach Ministries, served more than 370 households—double the expected number—highlighting the severe financial strain on federal workers. Participants like Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams describe the emotional and economic shock of losing job security, with one noting that their initial assumption of federal job safety has been shattered. Lawmakers remain divided, with GOP Senator Ron Johnson proposing partial payments for those still working, while Democrats call for full compensation for all federal workers. The event underscores both the human cost of political gridlock and the growing need for emergency support among public sector employees.
title: Federal workers form line down the block for food pantry as shutdown hits third-week mark
